questions.question: Which of the following conditions have an increased risk of breast carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Atypical hyperplasia significantly increases breast cancer risk (4-5x). Other listed conditions are generally benign with minimal risk.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: During a routine screening mammography, a 62-year-old teacher is informed that she has changes on her mammography, and she should consult her physician. She can be reassured that the findings that indicate a benign condition are which of the following?
options: Solid, clearly defined mass with irregular edges
Discrete, non-palpable mass enlarging compared to mammogram 1 year ago
questions.explanation: Coarse 'popcorn' calcifications indicate benign conditions like involuting fibroadenomas. Fine, clustered calcifications and stellate masses are suspicious for malignancy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 14-year-old black girl had her right breast removed because of a large mass. The tumor weighed 1400 g and was found to have a bulging, very firm, lobulated surface with a whorl-like pattern; This neoplasm is most likely:
questions.explanation: The description of a firm, lobulated, whorl-like mass is classic for a fibroadenoma (Giant/Juvenile in this age group).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman undergoes her first screening mammogram. Which of the following mammographic findings would require a breast biopsy?
options: Breast calcifications larger than 2 mm in diameter
Five or more clustered breast micro-calcifications per square centimeter
A density that effaces with compression
questions.explanation: Clustered microcalcifications (typically >5 per cmÂ²) are highly suspicious for Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS) or early invasive cancer and warrant a biopsy. Large calcifications are usually benign.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman have a 1to 2cm, slightly tender cystic mass in her breast; she has no axillary lymphadenopathy. What course would you follow?
options: Re-assurance and re-examination in the immediate post-menstrual period
Aspiration of the mass with cytological analysis
Mammography and re-evaluation of options with new information
questions.explanation: For a clinically cystic mass, fine-needle aspiration is both diagnostic and therapeutic. If the fluid is non-bloody and the mass resolves completely, no further treatment is needed.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman is found to have a 3-cm, firm, smooth mass in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. The mass is aspirated, and 10 mL of cloudy green fluid is removed. The appropriate management at this time is:
options: Cytologic evaluation of the aspirated fluid
questions.explanation: Cloudy green fluid is benign. If the mass disappears and fluid is not bloody, observation is standard. Cytology is not indicated for non-bloody fluid.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with eczematous lesion of her nipple. Which of the following statement(s) is/are true concerning her diagnosis and management?
options: Treatment is with warm compresses and oral antibiotics
Nipple biopsy with malignant cells invariably implies underlying invasive cancer
Always represents high-risk disease with significant metastatic risk
questions.explanation: This suggests Paget's disease, associated with underlying DCIS or invasive carcinoma. Standard treatment traditionally involves mastectomy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A breast cancer that is > 5 cm with no positive nodes or metastases is:
questions.explanation: A tumor > 5 cm (T3 N0) is technically Stage IIB, but historically or in this context, large tumors are often categorized as Stage III (locally advanced). The provided answer is Stage III.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Antibodies in colostrum are produced by:
questions.explanation: Plasma cells (differentiated B-lymphocytes) within the breast tissue produce secretory IgA, which is passed into colostrum.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Drugs that may produce gynecomastia include all of the following Except:
questions.explanation: Tamoxifen is an anti-estrogen used to treat breast conditions, including gynecomastia. Cimetidine, Diazepam, and Spironolactone are known causes of drug-induced gynecomastia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Estrogen receptor activity is clinically useful in predicting:
questions.explanation: The presence of Estrogen Receptors (ER+) predicts a favorable response to hormonal therapies such as Tamoxifen or Aromatase Inhibitors.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Fibro-cystic disease of the breast has been associated with elevated blood levels of:
questions.explanation: Fibrocystic changes are often driven by a relative or absolute hyperestrogenism or an imbalance between estrogen and progesterone.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: For pregnant women who are found to have breast cancer:
options: Termination of a first-trimester pregnancy is mandatory
Carcinoma of the breast behaves more aggressively in pregnant women owing to hormonal stimulation
Breast conservation is in-appropriate for 3rd-trimester pregnancies
Administration of adjuvant chemotherapy is safe for the fetus during the 2nd and 3rd trimesters
questions.explanation: Breast conservation requires radiation, which is traditionally contraindicated in pregnancy. (Note: Modern practice may allow BCS in 3rd trimester with delayed radiation).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Incisional biopsy of a breast mass in a 35-year-old woman demonstrates a hyper-cellular fibro-adenoma (cysto-sarcoma phylloides) at the time of frozen section. Appropriate management of this lesion could include:
options: Wide local excision with a rim of normal tissue
Excision, post-operative radiotherapy, and systemic chemotherapy
questions.explanation: Phyllodes tumors require wide local excision with clear margins to prevent recurrence. Axillary dissection is not routinely indicated.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Level II Axillary nodes:
options: Are located around the axillary vein
Are medial to or above the pectorals minor muscle
Are made up of the central and inter-pectoral nodes
Are made up of the external mammary and scapular nodes
questions.explanation: Level II nodes are located behind the pectoralis minor muscle. This group includes the central axillary nodes and Rotter's (interpectoral) nodes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS):
options: Can be diagnosed on mammogram by micro-calcifications adjacent to a mass
Can occur in men but is rare
Is usually diagnosed in the 6th decade of life
Progresses to lobular carcinoma in 50% of women
questions.explanation: While LCIS is often an incidental finding without specific mammographic signs, it can sometimes be associated with calcifications or found adjacent to other lesions that are biopsied.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Mammography is indicated for evaluation of a 40-year-old woman in all of the following situations Except:
options: Breast pain and discomfort in large fatty breasts without palpable nodules
Breasts with multiple nodules but no dominant area
Follow-up of the opposite breast after contralateral mastectomy for carcinoma
Presence of a small, smooth, solitary lesion as a substitute for biopsy
questions.explanation: Mammography should not be used as a substitute for biopsy in the presence of a solitary lesion. Tissue diagnosis (via biopsy or aspiration) is required to rule out malignancy definitively.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The BRCA genes are:
questions.explanation: BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes. Their mutation leads to a failure in DNA repair, increasing the risk of breast and ovarian cancers.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The false positive rate for mammography in the diagnosis of the breast cancer is:
questions.explanation: Approximately 10% of women screened are recalled for further testing (false positive), though only a small fraction of these have cancer.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The histological characteristic of Ductal Carcinoma In-situ is:
options: < Three cell layers protruding into the lumen of the duct
< Five cell layers protruding into the lumen of the duct
No invasion through the basement membrane
questions.explanation: The defining feature of carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is the proliferation of malignant cells without breaching the basement membrane.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The incidence of breast cancer:
options: Is related to dietary fat intake
Is related to vitamin C intake
questions.explanation: Age is the single most significant risk factor for breast cancer, with incidence rising steadily as women get older.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The treatment of choice for a 1.8 cm in diameter breast lump, NO, MO invasive breast cancer is:
options: Lumpectomy, sentinel node biopsy and radiation
Mastectomy with sentinel node biopsy and radiation
Mastectomy with axillary node dissection and radiation
questions.explanation: For early-stage breast cancer (T1 N0), breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy) combined with sentinel lymph node biopsy and adjuvant radiation is the standard of care.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: True statements about discharge from the nipple include:
options: Intermittent thin or milky discharge can be physiologic
Expressible nipple discharge is an indication for open biopsy
Bloody discharge is indicative of an underlying malignancy
Galactorrhea is indicative of an underlying malignancy
questions.explanation: Physiologic nipple discharge is often bilateral, multi-ductal, and can be thin or milky. Pathologic discharge is usually spontaneous, unilateral, and bloody or serous.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: True statements regarding Paget's disease of the breast include that:
options: Usually precedes development of Paget's disease of bone
Does not involve axillary lymph nodes because it is a manifestation of intra-ductal carcinoma only
Is adequately treated with wide excision when it presents as a mass
questions.explanation: Paget's disease of the breast classically presents as an eczema-like rash on the nipple and areola. It is distinct from Paget's disease of bone.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Uni-lateral bloody nipple discharge from one duct orifice studied with intra- ductal papilloma; it's most commonly caused by which of the following pathologic conditions?
questions.explanation: While papilloma is the commonest benign cause, among malignant/serious conditions listed, intraductal carcinoma (DCIS) is the primary concern for bloody discharge.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: When galactorrhoea occurs in a high school girl, a diagnostic associated finding would be:
questions.explanation: Galactorrhea in this age group may be caused by a pituitary adenoma (prolactinoma), which can compress the optic chiasm causing bitemporal hemianopia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following biopsy findings has the greatest relative risk for later carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia (ALH) carries a high relative risk (4-5x) for future breast cancer. The other options are either non-proliferative or proliferative without atypia, carrying lower risk.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following breast lesions are non-invasive malignancies?
options: Intra-ductal carcinoma of the Comedo type
Infiltrating ductal carcinoma and lobular carcinoma
Medullary carcinoma, including atypical medullary lesions
questions.explanation: Intraductal carcinoma (DCIS), including the Comedo type, is a non-invasive (in situ) malignancy. All other options listed are invasive carcinomas.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following increases risk of breast cancer?
options: Prolonged and multiple episodes of lactation
questions.explanation: Late menopause increases the duration of estrogen exposure, which is a key risk factor. Late menarche and lactation are protective.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is associated with an increased risk of in situ carcinoma of the breast?
questions.explanation: While atypia is the strongest risk, intraductal papillomas (especially multiple) are proliferative lesions associated with a slightly increased risk of malignancy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following pathologic findings is the strongest contraindication to breast preservation (lumpectomy with breast radiation) as primary treatment for a newly diagnosed breast cancer?
options: Grade 3, poorly differentiated, infiltrating ductal carcinoma
Extensive intra-ductal cancer around the invasive lesion
questions.explanation: A positive surgical margin that cannot be cleared is an absolute contraindication to breast-conserving therapy. Clear margins are essential to minimize local recurrence.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct concerning cysto-sarcoma phyllodes?
options: The tumor is most commonly seen in post-menopausal women
Total mastectomy is necessary for all patients with this diagnosis
Axillary lymph node dissection is not necessary for malignant cysto-sarcoma phyllodes
Most patients with the malignant variant of cysto-sarcoma phyllodes die of metastatic disease
questions.explanation: Phyllodes tumors spread primarily via the hematogenous route (blood) to the lungs. Lymphatic spread is rare, so axillary lymph node dissection is not routinely necessary.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true concerning radiation therapy after lumpectomy?
options: The total dose given to the breast is usually in the range of 2500 to 3000 cGy
Radiation to the axillary nodal bed is normally part of the procedure in most patients
Long-term complications of radiation therapy include rib fractures and arm oedema
Breast oedema and skin erythema usually resolves within a few weeks
questions.explanation: Radiation therapy can lead to long-term complications such as rib fractures, pulmonary fibrosis, and lymphedema (arm edema), especially if the axilla is irradiated.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which statement best describes lymphatic drainage from the breast?
options: All quadrants of the breast drain into both the axillary and the parasternal nodes
The areolar area of the breast drains into retrosternal internal mammary nodes
The lateral area of the breast drains into axillary nodes
The medial area of the breast drains into parasternal nodes
questions.explanation: While there is a predilection for lateral drainage to the axilla and medial to the parasternal nodes, lymphatic channels anastomose extensively, and any quadrant can potentially drain to either basin.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A breast cancer that is 3 cm in diameter with positive, moveable, ipsilateral nodes is:
questions.explanation: A tumor measuring 3 cm (T2) with positive mobile axillary nodes (N1) is classified as Stage IIB.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The benign disorder most likely to mimic carcinoma of the breast is:
questions.explanation: Sclerosing adenosis can present as a firm, palpable mass and may be associated with microcalcifications on mammography, making it difficult to distinguish from carcinoma without a biopsy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following are the most important and clinically useful risk factors for breast cancer?
options: Cysts, family history in immediate relatives, and gender
Age, gender, and family history in immediate relatives
questions.explanation: Female gender and increasing age are the strongest risk factors. A strong family history (first-degree relatives) is the next most significant factor.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true concerning adjuvant systemic therapy?
options: Adjuvant tamoxifen equals chemotherapy in post-menopausal node+ ER+ women
Tamoxifen clearly improves survival in all hormonal receptor-positive patients
CMF improves survival in both pre- and post-menopausal node-positive patients
There is no evidence to suggest a role for chemotherapy in node-negative patients
questions.explanation: In post-menopausal ER+ women, hormonal therapy is highly effective and often provides benefits comparable to chemotherapy with less toxicity.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 21-years old woman presents with an accidentally discovered breast mass. Which of the following statement is true concerning her diagnosis and treatment?
options: Mammography will play an important role in diagnosing the lesion
The mass should always be excised
The lesion should be considered pre-malignant
Ultrasonography is often useful in the differential diagnosis of this lesion
questions.explanation: In young women (<30), ultrasound is preferred over mammography due to dense breast tissue. It helps differentiate cysts from solid masses.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: 36F with 3-month bloody nipple discharge. Exam: small subareolar nodule. Pressure at 3 o'clock causes blood. Normal mammogram. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Intraductal papilloma is the most common cause of spontaneous, unilateral, bloody nipple discharge, often presenting as a small subareolar nodule.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: How many lactiferous ducts drain into the nipple of the mature female breast?
questions.explanation: Classically, it is taught that 15 to 20 lactiferous ducts drain into the nipple, though recent anatomical studies suggest the number may be lower.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following conditions leads to gynecomastia due to an increased estrogen?
questions.explanation: Liver diseases, such as hepatocellular carcinoma or cirrhosis, impair the liver's ability to metabolize estrogen, leading to high circulating levels and gynecomastia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: 50F, post-mastectomy for 2.5cm cancer, 3 positive nodes (Stage IIB). Metastatic survey negative. Receives chemo. Most common distant metastasis site?
questions.explanation: Bone is the most common site of distant metastasis for breast cancer.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Galactorrhea, a milky discharge from the nipple in nonpregnant women, is most likely to be associated with which of the following?
questions.explanation: A pituitary adenoma (prolactinoma) secretes prolactin, causing galactorrhea in non-pregnant, non-lactating women.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding investigations for breast cancer:
options: Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) and core biopsy are equally useful diagnostically
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can be a useful imaging tool in recurrent cases
PET-CT has no role in diagnosis of breast cancer
Ultrasound can also be used as a screening tool
50% of breast cancers are missed by population-based mammographic screening
questions.explanation: MRI is highly sensitive and is particularly useful for distinguishing scar tissue from recurrence and for screening high-risk patients.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Best treatment of chronic breast abscess is:
questions.explanation: Chronic abscesses often have thick walls and may not resolve with drainage or antibiotics alone. Excision of the abscess cavity is often required for cure.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Peu d'orange is due to:
questions.explanation: Peau d'orange (orange peel skin) is caused by cutaneous lymphatic edema, where the skin is tethered by the suspensory ligaments of Cooper, creating a pitted appearance.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: An 18-year-old presents with a well circumscribed 2-cm mass in her right breast. The mass is painless and has a rubbery consistency and discrete borders It appears to move freely through the breast tissue. What is the likeliest diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A painless, rubbery, mobile mass ('breast mouse') in a young woman is the classic presentation of a fibroadenoma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: 35F, mother had breast cancer, has fibrocystic breasts. Exam: multiple thickenings, no discrete mass. Which diagnostic test should be performed?
options: Bilateral breast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with gadolinium
Spot compression views if an area of discrete asymmetry or concerning calcifications is seen
questions.explanation: In patients with a significant family history and difficult-to-examine breasts (fibrocystic changes), MRI is a sensitive screening tool to rule out malignancy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman with BRAC-1 gene mutation seeks your advice about her known increased risk of breast cancer. You should recommend.
options: Mammograms/exam every 6 months until 50, then prophylactic mastectomy
Mammograms and physical examination every 6 months + tamoxifen
Prophylactic mastectomy and oophorectomy after childbearing
questions.explanation: Prophylactic mastectomy reduces risk by >90%. Prophylactic oophorectomy reduces both ovarian and breast cancer risk and is recommended after childbearing.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: 36F with substantial unilateral breast enlargement. Exam: large, firm tumor with early skin erosion. Favorable outlook anticipated if lesion is:
questions.explanation: Phyllodes tumors can be large and cause skin changes, but even malignant ones have a better prognosis than similar-sized carcinomas if excised completely.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A clinically positive sub clavicular lymph nodes is a:
questions.explanation: Subclavicular (apical) lymph nodes are located medial to the pectoralis minor muscle and are classified as Level III nodes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A woman has 3 cm breast mass non palpable LNs and no clinical evidence of distant metastasis, which is true?
options: Pathological evidence of cancer is necessary
Excision of the mass only is enough
questions.explanation: Clinical findings alone cannot confirm malignancy or final stage. Pathological confirmation (biopsy) is absolutely necessary for diagnosis and treatment planning.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About acute lactational breast abscess, one statement only is true.
options: Wide bore needle aspiration is superior as it avoids duct injury
Mammography is indicated if an abscess in suspected
Treatment is essentially conservative by antibiotics
questions.explanation: Breast abscesses are often multilocular, requiring breaking of loculi for effective drainage. Weaning is not mandatory.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About mammography all are true EXCEPT.
options: Expose the patient for some radiation
Is safe and can be repeated at any time
Malignancy can be proved my microcalcification
Thickened skin and retracted nipple can be noted in cancer patient
Irregular outline of the mass is another criterion of malignancy
questions.explanation: Mammography involves ionizing radiation. While safe for screening, it should not be repeated 'at any time' without indication to avoid unnecessary radiation exposure.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Absence of the breast (amastia) is associated with.
questions.explanation: Poland syndrome is a congenital anomaly characterized by the absence of the pectoralis major muscle and often ipsilateral breast hypoplasia or amastia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: After mastectomy, 52F has prominent medial scapula on protraction and weak abduction. Nerve injured?
questions.explanation: Injury to the Long Thoracic Nerve paralyzes the serratus anterior, causing 'winging of the scapula'.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following statements are true as regard benign breast disease, EXCEPT.
options: Benign breast disease is the most common cause of breast problems
Lipoma is a common condition of the breast
Traumatic fat necrosis can be mistaken for a carcinoma
30 per cent of breast cysts recur after aspiration
questions.explanation: Lipomas are relatively uncommon in the breast compared to fibroadenomas or cysts. The statement implies they are 'common', which is the intended false option.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: As regard prognosis of breast cancer All are true EXCEPT.
options: Worsen by detection of positive axillary LNs
better when strong positive estrogen receptor
Worse for invasive duct carcinoma than phyllodes tumor
questions.explanation: Tumor location (quadrant) does not significantly alter prognosis in modern treatment. Prognosis depends on Stage, Grade, and Biology.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Axillary LNs all are true EXCEPT.
options: Anterior, posterior, and lateral group are level II
Central l/n are related to intercostobrachial nerve
Apical group of l/n are level III
Positive axillary l/n affect the prognosis of breast cancer
questions.explanation: The anterior, posterior, and lateral lymph node groups are located lateral to the pectoralis minor and are classified as Level I nodes, not Level II.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Breast cyst all true EXCEPT.
options: Malignancy is suspected if the cyst is tense
Malignancy is suspected if the lump does not totally disappear after complete aspiration
Multiplicity of cyst raise suspicion of malignancy
Cyst excision is necessary in most cases
questions.explanation: Multiple cysts are a common feature of benign fibrocystic changes and do not inherently raise suspicion of malignancy. A solitary, complex, or recurrent cyst is more concerning.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Commonest histologic type of breast cancer is.
options: Infiltrating duct carcinoma not otherwise specified
questions.explanation: Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (NST/NOS) is the most common type, accounting for about 70-80% of all breast cancers.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Concerning sampling of a breast lump, all the following statement are true, EXCEPT.
options: The most accurate is excisional biopsy
Fine need aspiration cytology does not require general anesthesia
Fine need aspiration cytology shows tissue architecture
Frozen section biopsy is sometimes inconclusive
Turcot biopsy obtains a core of tissue
questions.explanation: FNAC provides cells, not tissue chunks. It does not preserve tissue architecture, making it impossible to distinguish in-situ from invasive cancer.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: During pregnancy, alveolar epithelium develops in the breast which is responsible after delivery for the production of milk. Which portion of alveolar epithelial cell is responsible for production of the fat present in human milk.
questions.explanation: Milk fat globules are formed in the cytoplasm and are secreted by budding off from the cell, taking part of the cell membrane (apocrine secretion).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Early breast cancer.
options: Means that microscopic metastasis are not present
Primary treatment is by surgery and/or radiotherapy
questions.explanation: Early breast cancer refers to potentially curable disease (Stages I and II) where primary treatment involves surgery (with or without radiation) to remove the tumor.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Fibrocystic disease of the breast, all true EXCEPT:
options: Nipple retraction may be the only clinical criteria
questions.explanation: Nipple retraction is a classic sign of malignancy. While severe fibrosis can cause it, it is not a typical 'only' criterion for benign disease.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: For Modified radical mastectomy, all the following are true, EXCEPT.
options: The areola and nipple are removed
The whole breast tissue is removed
Block dissection of axillary nodes requires excision of axillary vein
Nerve to serratus anterior should be spared
questions.explanation: In Modified Radical Mastectomy (MRM), the axillary vein is preserved. The lymph nodes are dissected from around it, but the vein itself is not excised.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In breast carcinoma, which one of the following statements is false?
options: Ductal carcinoma is the most common variant
Lobular carcinoma occurs in 15 per cent
There may be a combination of lobular and ductal features
Colloid, medullary and tubular carcinomas carry a poor prognosis
questions.explanation: Colloid (Mucinous), Medullary, and Tubular carcinomas are special types of breast cancer that generally carry a BETTER prognosis than standard infiltrating ductal carcinoma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In curable breast cancer in premenopausal females may be treated by the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Estrogen administration is contraindicated in treating breast cancer (as it fuels the tumor). Anti-estrogens (Tamoxifen) or ovarian suppression are used.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In the ANDI (abberations of normal development and involution) classification, a 2 cm fibroadenoma is considered.
questions.explanation: ANDI classifies a simple fibroadenoma as a 'Disorder' of development, whereas a Giant Fibroadenoma would be a 'Disease'.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In the treatment of breast cancer, which of the following statements are false?
options: There is a higher rate of local recurrence after conservative surgery and radiotherapy
After mastectomy, radiotherapy to the chest wall is not indicated
Sentinel lymph node biopsy should be done in clinically node-negative disease
Besides treating the patient, the role of axillary surgery is to stage the patient accurately
questions.explanation: Post-mastectomy radiotherapy is indicated for high-risk patients (e.g., T3/T4 tumors, >4 positive nodes, positive margins) to reduce local recurrence.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Mammary duct ectasia, all are true EXCEPT.
options: May produce mass similar to carcinoma in axillary tail
May produce non lactational mastitis and abscess
questions.explanation: Duct ectasia typically affects the major ducts in the subareolar region, not the axillary tail. It presents with nipple discharge and subareolar masses.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Moderate ductal hyperplasia of the breast is characterized by the microscopic finding of.
options: 3-4 cell layer above the basement membrane
5 or more cell layers above the basement membrane
Obstruction of >50% of the ductal lumen by hyperplastic cells
Obstruction of > 70%of the ductal lumen by hyperplastic cells
questions.explanation: Moderate to florid hyperplasia is defined by an increase in cell layers, typically described as 5 or more layers above the basement membrane.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Paget disease of the breast all are true EXCEPT.
options: Is an eczema of the skin
The disease is not related to Paget disease of bone
Is a duct carcinoma arising from main lactiferous ducts
questions.explanation: Paget's is an intraepidermal manifestation of underlying DCIS. While associated, defining it solely as a 'duct carcinoma arising from main ducts' is the intended false statement here.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding duct carcinoma in situ, one statement only is true.
options: May be discovered on screening mammography for asymptomatic women
Close observation is all that is needed
questions.explanation: DCIS is frequently detected as microcalcifications on screening mammography in asymptomatic women. It is a precursor to invasive cancer and requires treatment (excision), not just observation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The appropriate therapy of Paget`s disease of the nipple.
questions.explanation: Since Paget's disease indicates an underlying malignancy, surgical resection (mastectomy or breast-conserving surgery with nipple excision) is the appropriate treatment.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following about fibrocystic breast are all true, EXCEPT.
options: Is a cause of breast pain
questions.explanation: 'nipple retraction' is the exception for benign disease.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements about lymphatic drainage of the breast are all true, EXCEPT.
options: Lymph from medial half may drain in internal mammary nodes
From anywhere in the breast lymphatics drain mostly to axillary nodes
Levels I, II and III depend upon relationship with pectoralis minor
Level one axillary nodes is the highest in the axilla
Sentinel node is the earliest node involved
questions.explanation: Level I nodes are the *lowest* (lateral to pectoralis minor). Level III (apical) are the highest.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements about post-mastectomy arm edema, all are true, EXCEPT.
options: Adding radiotherapy to the axilla after clearance of lymph nodes increases the risk of edema
Rough dissection of the axillary vein at surgery is one of the causes
Insertion of an IV line in the ipsilateral upper limb is a predisposing factor
May be caused by recurrence in the axilla
questions.explanation: Post-mastectomy lymphedema is a chronic, often progressive condition, not 'always transient'.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements about pulmonary metastases of breast cancer are all true, EXCEPT:
options: If localized to one lung, pneumonectomy is indicated
questions.explanation: Lung metastases indicate systemic disease (Stage IV). Treatment is systemic; pneumonectomy is generally not indicated.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The medial mammary artery is a tributary of the.
questions.explanation: The medial breast is supplied by perforators of the Internal Mammary Artery. The option '2nd, 3rd, 4th intercostal arteries' likely refers to the anterior perforators at these intercostal spaces.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The treatment of choice of mondor`s disease.
options: Wide resection of the affected area
questions.explanation: Mondor's disease (thrombophlebitis of superficial breast veins) is a self-limiting condition treated conservatively with NSAIDs and warm compresses.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The treatment of choice of Zusak`s disease.
options: Wide resection of the affected areas
questions.explanation: Zuska's disease (recurrent subareolar abscess) typically requires drainage and antibiotics in the acute phase, though excision of the fistulous tract is needed for cure.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Treatment of cyclic mastalgia.
questions.explanation: Key selects 'Avoid breast support' (B), which contradicts standard advice to *use* support. This might be a typo for 'Proper support' or a trick. Reassurance (A) is the primary management.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: What is the hereditary factor percentage in female breast cancers.
questions.explanation: Hereditary breast cancer (e.g., BRCA mutations) accounts for approximately 5-10% of all breast cancer cases.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following about lobular carcinoma in situ is true.
options: Occurs at an older age than ductal carcinoma in situ
The majority of women with LCIS are premenopausal
LCIS is bilateral in 10-20% of women
Invasive ductal carcinoma occurs 5-10 years later in 75% of women
questions.explanation: LCIS is characteristically found in premenopausal women, unlike DCIS.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following hormones is primarily responsible for differentiation of breast ductal epithelium.
questions.explanation: Progesterone synergizes with estrogen for full differentiation (lobulo-alveolar). The key selects Progesterone.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is appropriate treatment for 3 cm fibroadenoma.
questions.explanation: A 3cm fibroadenoma can be managed by excision (if symptomatic/patient wish), cryoablation (emerging), or observation (if biopsy confirmed benign and stable). All are valid options.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following conditions increases a woman`s risk of breast cancer.
questions.explanation: Atypical hyperplasia (ductal or lobular) is a significant risk factor for breast cancer, increasing the relative risk by approximately 4-5 times compared to the general population.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Hematogenous spread of breast cancer may produce any of the following, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Bone metastases in breast cancer are typically osteolytic, leading to the release of calcium into the blood, resulting in **hypercalcemia**, not hypocalcemia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The axillary lymph nodes are divided into three levels I, II, III by.
questions.explanation: The Pectoralis Minor muscle serves as the anatomical landmark. Level I nodes are lateral to it, Level II are deep/posterior to it, and Level III are medial to it.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: When screening females for breast carcinoma, what is the most significant risk?
options: More than 2 first degree relatives with ovarian or breast carcinoma
Three previous breast biopsies in premenopausal females
questions.explanation: A strong family history (multiple first-degree relatives) suggests a hereditary syndrome, representing the highest risk factor.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The cause in skin dimpling in any fibrotic affection of:
questions.explanation: Skin dimpling is caused by the infiltration and fibrosis of the Suspensory Ligaments of Cooper, which tether the skin to the underlying parenchyma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Adjuvant chemotherapy is indicated in:
questions.explanation: Adjuvant chemotherapy is standard for high-risk features, including lymph node involvement, hormone receptor-negative status (e.g., Triple Negative), and other poor prognostic factors.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All the following are recognized side effects of radiotherapy EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Radiotherapy can cause local skin burns, pulmonary fibrosis (if lungs are irradiated), and endarteritis (vascular damage). 'None of the above' is the correct choice as no exception is listed.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: As regard incidence of cancer breast all correct EXCEPT:
options: Males are rare to be affected but with grave prognosis
questions.explanation: Nulliparity is a well-established risk factor for breast cancer. The incidence is higher, not rare, in nulliparous women compared to multiparous women.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Best treatment for duct papilloma is:
questions.explanation: Excision of the affected duct (microdochectomy) with a safety margin is the standard treatment to resolve the discharge and rule out any associated malignancy or atypia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Bleeding on zonal pressure is highly suggestive of:
questions.explanation: Bloody nipple discharge that can be elicited by pressure on a specific zone of the areola (trigger point) is highly characteristic of an intraductal papilloma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Cancer en cuirasse is:
questions.explanation: Cancer en cuirasse describes a rigid, armor-like chest wall caused by diffuse infiltration of the skin by carcinoma nodules combined with lymphatic obstruction (edema).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Chemotherapy is the primary palliative treatment in the following conditions:
questions.explanation: Systemic chemotherapy is the mainstay of treatment for metastatic disease, particularly when there is visceral crisis or the tumor is hormone receptor-negative.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Clinical findings of fibro adenosis include:
questions.explanation: Fibroadenosis (fibrocystic changes) typically presents with symptoms that fluctuate with the menstrual cycle, including pain (mastalgia), lumpiness, and occasionally discharge.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Contraindications to conservative surgery include:
questions.explanation: Conservative surgery is contraindicated if clear margins/cosmesis can't be achieved (large tumor), if radiation is impossible (prior XRT), or if local control isn't the priority (metastasis).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Cyst of BIood Good is:
questions.explanation: A Bloodgood cyst (blue-domed cyst) is a benign cyst found in fibrocystic disease that contains dark, altered blood, giving it a characteristic blue appearance.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Etiology of breast abscess include:
options: Due to Staph from baby mouth
questions.explanation: The most common breast abscess is lactational, caused by Staphylococcus aureus transmission from the infant's nasopharynx through nipple fissures, often associated with hygiene or latching issues.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Lobular carcinoma of breast All true EXCEPT:
options: Is more common than ductal carcinoma
In situ state is considered risk factor for malignancy
With in situ carcinoma mammography of both breasts is mandatory
questions.explanation: Invasive Ductal Carcinoma is the most common type (70-80%). Lobular carcinoma is less common (approx. 10-15%).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Massive swellings of the breast include all the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Atrophic scirrhous carcinoma is characterized by intense fibrosis that causes the breast to shrink and become hard, rather than forming a massive swelling.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Mondor's disease is:
options: An obscure type of thrombophlebitis particularly affecting veins of the breast
questions.explanation: Mondor's disease is a rare, benign, superficial thrombophlebitis of the subcutaneous veins of the breast and anterior chest wall.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Risk factors of cancer breast include all the following EXCEPT:
options: Mutation in suppressor genes (BRCA l, Il)
questions.explanation: Prolonged lactation is a protective factor against breast cancer. The other options are established risk factors.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Signs of pus formation are the following EXCEPT:
options: No response to medical treatment for 48 hours
Fluctuation occurs early in breast abscess
questions.explanation: Fluctuation is typically a late sign in breast abscesses because the breast tissue is divided by fibrous septa which limit the movement of fluid.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The commonest route of infection of breast abscess is:
options: Along artificial passages like fissures or crocks of nipple and areola
Local extension from infection of the chest wall muscles or ribs
questions.explanation: Bacteria typically enter through the nipple ducts (natural passages) or fissures during lactation to cause an abscess.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following is contraindication to conservative breast surgery:
questions.explanation: Mastitis carcinomatosa (Inflammatory Breast Cancer) requires systemic therapy and mastectomy, not conservation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following is treatment of choice in pericanalicular fibroadenoma:
questions.explanation: Fibroadenomas are well-encapsulated benign tumors. The standard surgical treatment, if indicated, is enucleation (shelling out the mass).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The main presentation of Paget disease is:
questions.explanation: Paget's disease presents as a chronic, eczematous, scaling, or ulcerating lesion of the nipple and areola, typically unilateral.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Treatment of fibro adenosis all true EXCEPT:
options: Surgery is reserved to complicated cases
questions.explanation: Initial treatment involves reassurance and mild measures. Anti-estrogens (e.g., Tamoxifen) are reserved for severe cases.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Triple assessment include the following except:
questions.explanation: Triple assessment refers to the combination of Clinical Examination, Imaging (Mammography/Ultrasound), and Pathology (Cytology/Biopsy). Routine laboratory investigations are not part of this triad.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 30-year-old female presented with serosanguious discharge from the right nipple. Examination revealed no palpable masses. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Spontaneous, unilateral, serosanguinous nipple discharge in the absence of a mass is the classic clinical presentation of an intraductal papilloma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: 50F with 6-month pruritus/eczema of nipple. Biopsy: Paget's cells. Treatment:
questions.explanation: Paget's indicates underlying malignancy. The key specifies 'Radical Mastectomy' (likely Modified Radical), emphasizing clearance of underlying disease.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A palpable breast mass in a woman of 40 years
options: Is most likely to be cyst or carcinoma
Mammography alone is 90% sensitive for malignancy
May be DCIS & Triple assessment is 90% diagnostic
questions.explanation: Triple assessment (Clinical, Radiological, Pathological) provides diagnostic accuracy >90%.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Bilateral primary breast cancer is most likely to develop in association with:
questions.explanation: Invasive Lobular Carcinoma and Lobular Carcinoma In Situ (LCIS) have a much higher rate of bilaterality and multicentricity compared to ductal carcinomas.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Causes of gynecomastia:
questions.explanation: Gynecomastia causes include liver failure (estrogen metabolism), drugs (Digitalis, Spironolactone), and androgen deficiency.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Clinical features of breast cancer which are associated with a particularly poor prognosis include:
options: Edema of the skin of the breast
questions.explanation: These signs (peau d'orange, ulceration, arm edema) indicate locally advanced breast cancer (T4) or extensive nodal involvement, which carries a poor prognosis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Concerning mastitis carcinoma, the incorrect statement among the following is that it:
options: Occurs most often during pregnancy and lactation
Is often misdiagnosed as acute mastitis
Is associated with a palpable mass in the breast
Causes painless enlargement of the axillary glands
questions.explanation: Mastitis carcinomatosa (Inflammatory Breast Cancer) typically presents as diffuse induration and erythema of the breast without a distinct, discrete palpable mass.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In hard fiproadenoma of the female breast, it is untrue that it:
options: Has a peak incidence in the second and third decades
questions.explanation: Fibroadenomas are benign lesions. Malignant transformation is extremely rare (<0.1%), making the statement 'May turn malignant' practically untrue in the context of common clinical features.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Incurable breast cancer in premenopausal females may be treated by the following except:
questions.explanation: Administering estrogen is contraindicated as it stimulates tumor growth. Treatment involves hormonal blockade (Tamoxifen, ovarian suppression) or chemotherapy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Indian file arrangement is a histological picture of the following breast tumor:
questions.explanation: Infiltrating Lobular Carcinoma cells characteristically align in a single file ('Indian file') due to a lack of E-cadherin adhesion molecules.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Risk factors in the development of breast cancer include the following except:
questions.explanation: Late menarche reduces lifetime estrogen exposure and is a protective factor against breast cancer. Early menarche is the risk factor.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Soft tissue mammography is most valuable in:
options: Differentiating of benign from malignant masses
Mass screening of women of child-bearing age
questions.explanation: The primary advantage of mammography is the ability to detect non-palpable cancers (e.g., microcalcifications) before they become clinically evident.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The acronym QUART stands for:
questions.explanation: QUART is an acronym for breast-conserving therapy consisting of **Qu**adrantectomy, **A**xillary **R**esection, and **R**adiotherapy (**T**herapy).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements about fibroadenosis of the breast are true except that:
options: It manifests itself by pain or lumps
Symptoms vary with the stages of the menstrual cycle
Unopposed estrogen stimulation is a major aetiologic
Large lumps may contain fluid on aspiration
It can usually be clinically differentiated from carcinoma
questions.explanation: Fibroadenosis (fibrocystic change) often presents as irregular, firm lumps that are clinically indistinguishable from carcinoma, requiring imaging and biopsy for differentiation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The median survival untreated breast cancer is:
questions.explanation: Historical records of untreated breast cancer indicate a median survival time of approximately 2.5 to 3 years from the onset of symptoms.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common site for scirrhous carcinoma of the breast is:
questions.explanation: The upper outer quadrant contains the largest volume of breast tissue and is the location for approximately 50% of all breast cancers.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most frequent histologic type of breast carcinoma is:
questions.explanation: Infiltrating (Invasive) Ductal Carcinoma is the most common histological subtype, accounting for about 70-80% of breast cancer cases.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: When breast cancer is treated by partial mastectomy or lumpectomy, further therapy should include:
questions.explanation: Adjuvant radiation therapy is mandatory after lumpectomy to eradicate microscopic residual disease and reduce local recurrence rates.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: When stage I breast cancer is treated by partial mastectomy and dissection, further therapy should include:
questions.explanation: Even in Stage I disease, breast-conserving surgery must be followed by radiation therapy to the breast to ensure oncological safety.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following statement(s) is/are associated with gynecomastia?
options: If the disease is unilateral, it is unlikely drug-related
The standard surgical treatment is subcutaneous mastectomy
The presence of gynecomastia is often associated with the subsequent development of breast cancer
A formal endocrine evaluation is indicated in most patients with gynecomastia
questions.explanation: Subcutaneous mastectomy (excision of glandular tissue while preserving the nipple and skin) is the standard surgical treatment for persistent, symptomatic gynecomastia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Probe test can differentiate cystosarcoma phylloides from:
questions.explanation: A probe can be passed between a Phyllodes tumor and the skin because it does not infiltrate the skin, unlike advanced breast cancer which fixes and infiltrates the skin.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most useful investigation for a breast with a prosthesis is:
questions.explanation: MRI is the preferred imaging modality for women with breast implants, as it allows visualization of the breast tissue without the obstruction caused by the implant on mammography.
questions.subject: General Surgery
